awd_titl_txt: The Shape of Data: Using Topology and Geometry in Statistics
awd_abstract_narration:
In our modern society, technical advances constantly give rise to new data collection mechanisms that allow scientists to ask questions of ever-increasing complexities. The field of statistics is pressed to develop methodologies that can be used for answering such scientific challenges. Many of these scientific challenges can be addressed by first attempting to decrease size and complexity of the data through what is called feature extraction. In a second step these features are used to devise sound statistical methodologies. This project considers extracting information about the shape of the data, and is developing and studying statistical and machine learning methodologies based on these features. The outcomes of this project are expected to impact the fields of statistics, machine learning and various fields of application. Existing collaborations of the PI with biologists, animal scientists and material scientists, will also facilitate dissemination to these fields. This project will also provide training opportunities for both graduate and undergraduate students. 

The contributions of this project will lie in the intersection of statistics and machine learning. They will enhance toolboxes and advance knowledge through the derivation of novel methodologies, through developing a deep understanding of these methodologies by performing relevant theoretical analyses, and by providing implementations of the methodologies that are useful for practical purposes. More specifically, this project will (i) study the role of the Hodge Laplacian in the context of analyzing higher-relational data, including its role in clustering; (ii) derive theoretical results about stabilizing statistics such as Betti-curves that allow the construction  of asymptotically exact bootstrap based confidence intervals for functionals of persistent Betti-curves;  (iii) develop a novel, statistically enhanced persistence diagram thought the use of multiple testing, and (iv) Implementations will allow the exploration of finite sample properties of the new methods.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The scientific contributions of this project consist in (i) developing novel statistical methodologies for modern data analysis, and (ii) in analyzing the performance of such methodologies both theoretically and numerically. The findings of the project were then disseminated to the scientific community through publications in scientific journals and through oral presentations at conferences and workshops. Moreover, the project has contributed to the training and professional development of graduate students. 

The methodologies considered in this project have in common that they have a strong geometric component that provides an intuitive understanding to the users about how the methods work. While such intuition is very important, it often also comes with pitfalls. This motivates a more formal, theoretical analyses of the methodologies. Combining these two aspects, the intuition on the one hand, and the theoretical analyses on the other, then results in deep insights and understanding of these methods. Such insights are of critical importance for a solid scientific interpretation of a data analysis. 

More specifically, the project (I) developed and analyzed methodologies for anomaly detection, and (II) provided novel statistical insights for quantities describing the "shape of data', such as the Euler characteristic and Betti numbers. Important aspects of part (I) are that the method is widely applicable to modern data sets, and that it comes with a visualization tool to aid the statistical analysis. The quantities considered in part (II) lie in the core of the subfield of topological data analysis that has emerged more recently and is very popular in applications. Deepening their theoretical analysis, as was done in this project,  thus has a broad impact. In summary, the scientific contributions of the project have advanced the toolbox of geometric and topological data analysis and they have deepened the insights about the statistical behavior of the considered quantities.

Training and professional development of graduate students happened at various levels. On the scientific side, two doctoral students have been working on aspects of this project towards their PhD degree in statistics. In regular meetings, these doctoral students were provided with information and insights into different career paths. Moreover, the project leader also presented several lecture series on geometric and topological aspects of statistics to a larger groups of graduate students, both at his home institution and also internationally.
